question: While selecting a test to use in school, a school psychologist discovered that a particular test was not very consistent or stable over time. In other words, some test takers' scores varied each time they took it. The school psychologist can most likely conclude which of the following?

choices.A: The test is biased.
choices.B: The test has poor evidence of validity.
choices.C: The test makers did not use an appropriate norming sample.
choices.D: The test is not reliable.

rationale: The test is not reliable. Reliability refers to an instrument's consistency or stability in measurement.

question: Which of the following is a commonly used metric for establishing reliability of measurement within the context of a single-subject design?

choices.A: Internal consistency
choices.B: Test-retest reliability
choices.C: Interobserver agreement
choices.D: The generalizability coefficient

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Although all responses represent common reliability metrics, only interobserver agreement is commonly used within the context of single-subject design. In fact, the other metrics would be difficult to calculate given the nature of single-case data.

question: Which of the following is the best example of interrater reliability?

choices.A: A student receives similar scores when tested on two different days.
choices.B: Two observers recording the same behavior at the same time obtain similar data.
choices.C: A test measures what it is supposed to measure.
choices.D: Different items on a test measure the same construct.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Interrater reliability is agreement between different raters or observers.

question: A school psychologist is reviewing a new behavior rating scale before using it with students. The psychologist asks a team of experts to evaluate whether the items adequately cover the construct of attention difficulties. Which type of validity evidence is the psychologist gathering?

choices.A: Face validity based on how reasonable the items appear
choices.B: Content validity based on expert review of item coverage
choices.C: Criterion-related validity based on correlation with another measure
choices.D: Construct validity based on factor analysis of scale scores

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Content validity is supported when experts review whether items adequately represent the construct. The other options are incorrect because face validity is superficial, criterion validity requires correlation with an external measure, and construct validity relies on theoretical and statistical evidence such as factor analysis.

question: A school psychologist wants to determine whether scores from a new reading screener predict students' performance on the state reading assessment later in the year. Which type of validity evidence is being examined?

choices.A: Predictive criterion-related validity using later outcome scores
choices.B: Concurrent criterion-related validity using same-day scores
choices.C: Content validity based on alignment to reading standards
choices.D: Face validity based on how clear the items seem

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Predictive criterion-related validity examines whether a measure predicts future performance on an external criterion. The other options are incorrect because concurrent validity uses measures taken at the same time, content validity involves expert judgment of coverage, and face validity is not sufficient evidence of validity.

question: Which of the following types of validity evidence is most directly assessed by examining the relationship between test scores and an external criterion?

choices.A: Content validity
choices.B: Construct validity
choices.C: Criterion-related validity
choices.D: Face validity

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Criterion-related validity examines the relationship between test scores and external criteria.

question: A student's score on a reading comprehension test is in the 80th percentile. Which of the following best explains the student's score?

choices.A: The student scored higher than 20 percent of all the students who took the test.
choices.B: The student earned 80 percent correct on the test.
choices.C: The student scored 80 out of 100 questions correct on the test.
choices.D: The student scored higher than 80 percent of all the students who took the test.

rationale: The percentile rank of a score is the percentage of scores in its frequency distribution that are equal to or lower than it.

question: A test has a mean score of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. A student receives a standard score of 85. The student's z score would be
rationale: The z-score (which is the location on the normal curve identifying how far from the mean the score lies) can be calculated by subtracting the mean score from the obtained score and dividing that number by the standard deviation.

question: A school psychologist evaluates a child's ability to attend to information, hold information in immediate awareness, concentrate, and perform a mental operation. Which of the following is the school psychologist measuring?

choices.A: Verbal comprehension
choices.B: Working memory
choices.C: Processing speed
choices.D: Fluid reasoning

rationale: Working memory refers to the ability to attend to information, hold the information in immediate awareness, and work with the information in some way.

question: A school psychologist administers an intelligence test to a student. The student earns a Full Scale IQ score of 85 with a 95% confidence interval of 80-90. Which of the following is the best interpretation of this result?

choices.A: The student's true intellectual ability score is exactly 85 with zero error
choices.B: There is a 95% probability that the student's true IQ falls between 80 and 90.
choices.C: The student will always score between 80 and 90 on this test.
choices.D: The student's IQ score is significantly below average.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. The confidence interval indicates the range within which the true score likely falls.

question: A school psychologist is reviewing the results of a standardized test. The test manual indicates that the test has a reliability coefficient of .95. Which of the following best describes what this means?

choices.A: The test measures what it claims to measure 95% of the time.
choices.B: Scores on this test are highly consistent and stable.
choices.C: 95% of students will score within the average range.
choices.D: The test predicts future performance with 95% accuracy.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. A reliability coefficient of .95 indicates high consistency of scores.

question: Which of the following statistical concepts is most useful for understanding how much variability in a student's test scores is due to measurement error?

choices.A: The arithmetic mean of the scores
choices.B: The standard deviation of the distribution
choices.C: Standard error of measurement
choices.D: Correlation coefficient

rationale: Option (C) is correct. SEM indicates variability due to measurement error.

question: A school psychologist is interpreting results from a cognitive assessment. The student's Verbal Comprehension Index score is significantly higher than the Perceptual Reasoning Index score. Which of the following interpretations is most appropriate?

choices.A: The student definitely meets the criteria for a specific learning disability in reading
choices.B: The Full Scale IQ is a valid representation of the student's overall ability.
choices.C: The student shows a pattern of relative strengths and weaknesses that should be considered in educational planning.
choices.D: The student should be referred for further evaluation of nonverbal learning disability.

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Score differences indicate patterns to consider in planning.

question: A school psychologist is meeting with a parent who is concerned about their child's progress. The parent asks the school psychologist to explain what a percentile rank means. Which of the following explanations would be most accurate and helpful?

choices.A: It shows the percentage of questions your child answered correctly.
choices.B: It shows how your child's performance compares to other students of the same age or grade.
choices.C: It predicts your child's future academic success.
choices.D: It shows the percentage of content your child has mastered.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Percentile ranks compare performance to same-age/grade peers.

question: Which of the following cognitive processes is most directly related to a student's ability to solve novel problems?

choices.A: Processing speed
choices.B: Working memory
choices.C: Fluid reasoning
choices.D: Long-term retrieval

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Fluid reasoning involves solving novel problems.

question: A school psychologist administers an achievement test to a student. The student earns a standard score of 85 in reading comprehension. This score falls in which range?

choices.A: Below average
choices.B: The Average range
choices.C: Above average
choices.D: Below Average

rationale: Option (B) is correct. A standard score of 85 falls within the average range (typically 85-115).

question: A school psychologist is interpreting data from a progress monitoring graph. The data show a flat trend line after four weeks of intervention. Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation?

choices.A: The intervention is working well
choices.B: The student is making adequate progress
choices.C: The intervention may need to be modified or intensified
choices.D: The student should be referred for special education

rationale: Option (C) is correct. A flat trend suggests the intervention needs modification.

question: A behavior screener accurately identifies most students who do not have significant behavior concerns, but it sometimes flags students who are actually doing fine. This pattern indicates the screener has relatively high ____ and lower ____.

choices.A: sensitivity; specificity
choices.B: specificity; sensitivity
choices.C: sensitivity; predictive validity
choices.D: specificity; construct validity

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Correctly identifying students without concerns reflects high specificity, while incorrectly flagging some students suggests lower sensitivity is not the issue, but rather more false positives associated with specificity tradeoffs. The other options are incorrect because sensitivity concerns true positives, and predictive or construct validity are not classification accuracy indices.

question: A district is selecting a brief screener to identify students who may be at risk for depression. The district wants to minimize the chance of missing students who truly need follow-up support. Which test characteristic is most important to prioritize?

choices.A: High sensitivity to reduce false negatives
choices.B: High specificity to reduce false positives
choices.C: High internal consistency to reduce score variability
choices.D: High face validity to increase student cooperation

rationale: Option (A) is correct. High sensitivity reduces false negatives and helps ensure at-risk students are not missed. The other options are incorrect because specificity reduces false positives, internal consistency addresses reliability rather than classification accuracy, and face validity alone does not ensure accurate identification.

question: Which of the following is an example of test sensitivity?

choices.A: Performance on the DIBELS reading fluency measure was found to correlate well with other established measures of reading fluency.
choices.B: Two different teachers complete the BASC-3 for the same student, and similar scores are found across most subscales between the two teachers.
choices.C: The WISC-V accurately predicts which students are likely to be diagnosed with a specific learning disability.
choices.D: The Woodcock-Johnson IV shows good consistency of results over multiple administrations across most subtests.

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Test sensitivity refers to a test's rate of "true positives" and indicates that a test is able to accurately identify those who actually have a particular disorder or disability.

question: A school psychologist is evaluating David, a fourth-grade student, for special education eligibility. Which of the following sources of data would be most important for the school psychologist to gather to determine whether David qualifies for special education services?

choices.A: Medical records, teacher interview, and behavior checklist
choices.B: Cognitive assessment, achievement assessment, and progress monitoring data
choices.C: Parent interview, classroom observation, and medical records
choices.D: Universal screening data, teacher interview, and parent interview

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Cognitive and achievement assessments along with progress monitoring data are most directly relevant to determining eligibility.

question: A school psychologist is working with a student who has been identified as having a specific learning disability in reading. Which of the following assessment approaches would be most appropriate to determine the student's instructional level?

choices.A: Administering a standardized achievement test
choices.B: Administering curriculum-based measurement probes
choices.C: Administering a standardized intelligence test
choices.D: Conducting a classroom observation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. CBM probes are designed to determine instructional levels and monitor progress.

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate use of intelligence test scores in educational decision-making?

choices.A: To rank students by ability and track them into different educational programs
choices.B: To predict a student's potential for academic achievement and success in life
choices.C: To identify discrepancies between ability and achievement for eligibility determination
choices.D: To determine the specific academic interventions a student needs

rationale: Option (C) is correct. IQ scores are commonly used to identify ability-achievement discrepancies for eligibility purposes.

question: Which of the following assessment tools would be most appropriate for identifying students who may be at risk for reading difficulties at the beginning of first grade?

choices.A: A standardized reading achievement test
choices.B: A phonemic awareness screening measure
choices.C: A comprehensive reading diagnostic assessment
choices.D: A reading interest inventory

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Phonemic awareness screening identifies early reading risk efficiently.

question: Which of the following assessment tools would be most appropriate for measuring a student's executive functioning skills?

choices.A: A standardized achievement test
choices.B: A behavior rating scale designed to assess executive function
choices.C: A projective personality assessment
choices.D: A universal reading screener for academic progress monitoring

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Executive function rating scales specifically measure these skills.

question: Which of the following assessment approaches would be most appropriate for evaluating a preschool child's development?

choices.A: Standardized intelligence testing with verbal and nonverbal subtests
choices.B: Developmental screening followed by comprehensive evaluation if concerns are identified
choices.C: Academic achievement testing
choices.D: Self-report questionnaires about social-emotional functioning

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Developmental screening with follow-up evaluation is appropriate for preschoolers.

question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of norm-referenced tests?

choices.A: They measure a student's mastery of specific content standards.
choices.B: They compare a student's performance to that of a representative sample.
choices.C: They assess a student's rate of progress over time.
choices.D: They are designed to be administered by classroom teachers.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Norm-referenced tests compare performance to a normative sample.

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate use of standardized test norms?

choices.A: To determine whether a student has mastered grade-level content standards
choices.B: To compare a student's performance to that of same-age or same-grade peers
choices.C: To measure a student's rate of improvement over time
choices.D: To identify specific skills that need remediation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Norms are used to compare performance to same-age or grade peers.

question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of criterion-referenced tests?

choices.A: They compare a student's performance to a normative sample.
choices.B: They assess mastery of specific skills or content standards.
choices.C: They are typically administered once per year.
choices.D: They require standardized administration procedures.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Criterion-referenced tests measure mastery of specific standards.

question: A school psychologist is working with a student who is not responding to a Tier 2 reading intervention. The psychologist first collects baseline oral reading fluency data for several days, then implements a revised intervention and continues collecting daily fluency data while graphing performance to compare baseline and intervention phases. Which type of assessment approach is being used?

choices.A: Summative assessment to evaluate final outcomes at the end of instruction
choices.B: Norm-referenced assessment to compare the student to grade-level peers
choices.C: Single-subject assessment to evaluate individual change across baseline and intervention phases
choices.D: Diagnostic assessment used only once to identify a disability category

rationale: Option (C) is correct. A single-subject approach uses repeated measurement of an individual student over time and compares performance across phases (for example, baseline versus intervention) to determine whether the intervention is producing meaningful change. The other options are incorrect because summative assessment is end-of-period evaluation, norm-referenced assessment focuses on comparisons to a norm group rather than phase change, and diagnostic assessment is not limited to a single administration nor is it defined by baseline versus intervention phase comparisons.

question: A school psychologist graphs a student's daily on-task behavior for two weeks, introduces a self-monitoring intervention, and continues daily measurement to evaluate change for that student. Which assessment approach is being used?

choices.A: Summative assessment focused on final outcomes
choices.B: Single-subject design using repeated measures over time
choices.C: Formative assessment used to adjust whole-class instruction
choices.D: Diagnostic assessment used to establish eligibility categories

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Single-subject designs use repeated measures to evaluate change for an individual following an intervention. The other options are incorrect because summative and formative assessments do not emphasize individual experimental evaluation, and diagnostic assessments are not defined by repeated measurement across phases.

question: A fourth-grade teacher gives students short weekly quizzes and uses the results to adjust small-group instruction the following week. Which type of assessment is the teacher using?

choices.A: Formative assessment used to guide instruction over time
choices.B: Summative assessment used to evaluate end-of-unit mastery
choices.C: Screening assessment used to identify risk status once a year
choices.D: Norm-referenced assessment used to compare students to peers

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Formative assessments are ongoing and inform instructional decisions. The other options are incorrect because summative assessments occur at the end of instruction, screenings focus on risk identification, and norm-referenced tests compare performance to a normative sample.

question: Which of the following describes a key difference between formative and summative assessments?

choices.A: Formative assessments occur at the end of instruction, while summative assessments occur during instruction.
choices.B: Formative assessments are used to guide instruction, while summative assessments are used to evaluate learning at the end of instruction.
choices.C: Formative assessments are graded, while summative assessments are not graded.
choices.D: Formative assessments are used to rank students, while summative assessments are not used for ranking.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Formative assessments guide instruction while summative assessments evaluate cumulative learning.

question: Which of the following is an example of progress monitoring?

choices.A: Completing cognitive testing to identify intellectual ability
choices.B: Completing classroom observations of a student for the purpose of identifying the function of a behavior
choices.C: Completing reading curriculum-based measures weekly to identify reading growth
choices.D: Administering a universal reading screener to all students

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Progress monitoring involves frequent assessment of a skill over time to determine student growth.

question: Which of the following is a primary advantage of using curriculum-based measurement for progress monitoring?

choices.A: It provides detailed diagnostic information about specific skill deficits.
choices.B: It can be administered frequently without practice effects.
choices.C: It compares students to a national normative sample.
choices.D: It measures a comprehensive range of academic skills.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. CBM can be administered frequently without practice effects impacting results.

question: Which of the following is a primary characteristic of effective progress monitoring?

choices.A: It is administered at the beginning and end of the school year.
choices.B: It is administered frequently using standardized procedures.
choices.C: It compares student performance to grade-level expectations.
choices.D: It provides detailed diagnostic information about specific skills.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Effective progress monitoring is frequent and standardized.

question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of universal screening?

choices.A: To diagnose specific disabilities in students
choices.B: To identify students who may need additional support or intervention
choices.C: To determine eligibility for special education services
choices.D: To evaluate the effectiveness of classroom instruction

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Universal screening identifies students who may need additional support.

question: A school psychologist is analyzing universal screening data for a school. Which of the following would be most useful for identifying students who may need Tier 2 support?

choices.A: Comparing students' scores to grade-level benchmarks
choices.B: Calculating the overall school average
choices.C: Reviewing only the scores of students already receiving special education
choices.D: Looking at last year's data only

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Comparing to benchmarks identifies students needing additional support.

question: Viraag, a third-grade student, was referred by his teacher to the school psychologist due to concerns about his ability to perform expected grade-level math tasks. Which of the following statements best reflects the school psychologist's first step in addressing the concern?

choices.A: The school psychologist identifies a high-achieving student in the class who can serve as a peer tutor for Viraag.
choices.B: The school psychologist asks the teacher to identify the typical math performance of a different student in the class who performs at grade level.
choices.C: The school psychologist obtains permission to assess Viraag with an individually administered math diagnostic achievement test.
choices.D: The school psychologist selects a math-skills worksheet that can be administered to the entire class and that represents skills that the average student should successfully complete.

rationale: Administering a worksheet to the whole class is relatively unobtrusive and will allow the school psychologist to assess how students in this class are performing to ensure there is no deficit in teaching.

question: Which of the following is the first step in selecting an appropriate academic intervention?

choices.A: Selecting an appropriate evidence-based intervention
choices.B: Monitoring the student's ongoing academic performance data
choices.C: Assessing the student's current level of functioning to identify the skill deficit
choices.D: Evaluating the effectiveness of the intervention

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Identifying the skill deficit is the first step in selecting an intervention. It is necessary to know what the student's baseline abilities are to know what to target with the intervention.

question: A school psychologist has recently been hired to work at an elementary school. The principal informs the psychologist that over the past year, there has been an increase in behavior referrals for students on the playground and in the hallways. Which of the following steps should the school psychologist take first?

choices.A: Meet with classroom teachers to identify strategies they use for playground and hallway transitions
choices.B: Review the referral data to identify common problem behaviors and the locations where they occur most frequently
choices.C: Contact the district's behavior specialist to schedule professional development on positive behavior support strategies
choices.D: Present a plan to implement a schoolwide positive behavior intervention and support (PBIS) program

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Data-based decision making requires reviewing data before making recommendations.

question: A school psychologist notices that a disproportionate number of students from one ethnic group are being referred for special education evaluation. Which of the following is the most appropriate first step to address this issue?

choices.A: Declining to evaluate students from that ethnic group
choices.B: Examining referral practices and data to identify potential sources of bias
choices.C: Recommending fewer students from that group for special education services
choices.D: Using only assessments developed for that specific ethnic group

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Examining data helps identify potential sources of disproportionality.

question: Before conducting an assessment, a school psychologist should:

choices.A: Review background information including student records, medical records, previous interventions, and developmental history
choices.B: Relying primarily on teacher report without other sources
choices.C: Implement an intervention program
choices.D: Implement an intervention without reviewing assessment data

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Background information = student records, medical records, previous interventions, developmental history. Appropriate use: review before assessment, understand context, identify patterns, inform assessment planning. Medical records with parent authorization appropriate when health issues may affect learning/behavior. question: A school psychologist is asked to evaluate a student for attention difficulties. Which of the following sources of information would be most appropriate to review before beginning testing?

choices.A: Developmental history, prior interventions, and relevant health information
choices.B: Only the student's most recent report card and classroom grades
choices.C: Only the student's performance on the last state assessment
choices.D: Only the teacher's personal opinion about the student's effort level

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Reviewing developmental history, intervention data, and relevant health information provides important context for assessment planning. The other options are incorrect because each uses a limited data source and ignores essential background factors.

question: Before initiating a comprehensive evaluation, a school psychologist reviews a student's prior evaluations, attendance history, intervention records, and medical information related to seizures. What is the primary purpose of reviewing this background information first?

choices.A: To identify contextual factors that inform assessment planning and interpretation
choices.B: To determine the student's final eligibility category without further testing
choices.C: To replace standardized assessment with record review alone
choices.D: To create a discipline plan based only on past referrals

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Background information provides context, informs test selection, and supports accurate interpretation of results. The other options are incorrect because records do not replace assessment, do not determine eligibility by themselves, and are not used solely to create discipline plans.

question: A second-grade student who recently moved to the United States performs poorly on a cognitive measure. The school psychologist provides brief instruction on the task demands and then re-administers similar items to see how quickly the student learns. This approach is best described as which type of assessment?

choices.A: Dynamic assessment using a test-teach-retest model
choices.B: Norm-referenced assessment using standard score comparisons
choices.C: Summative assessment evaluating learning at the end of instruction
choices.D: Curriculum-based measurement focused on weekly skill growth

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Dynamic assessment uses a test-teach-retest approach to evaluate learning potential and responsiveness to instruction. The other options are incorrect because they focus on static comparison, end-of-unit evaluation, or repeated academic progress monitoring rather than learning potential.

question: A school psychologist is concerned that a student's low scores may reflect limited prior educational opportunities rather than true learning difficulty. Which assessment approach would best help evaluate the student's responsiveness to instruction?

choices.A: Administering a test-teach-retest procedure and noting improvement
choices.B: Administering a standardized test once and reporting percentile rank
choices.C: Comparing teacher ratings across settings for consistency over time
choices.D: Reviewing end-of-year grades to determine long-term academic trends

rationale: Option (A) is correct. A test-teach-retest model is central to dynamic assessment and evaluates learning potential through responsiveness to instruction. The other options are incorrect because they rely on static or indirect indicators that do not measure change following teaching.

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate use of dynamic assessment?

choices.A: To compare a student's performance to national norms
choices.B: To assess a student's learning potential and responsiveness to instruction
choices.C: To diagnose specific learning disabilities
choices.D: To measure achievement in specific academic content areas

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Dynamic assessment evaluates learning potential and responsiveness.

question: A school psychologist is conducting an evaluation for a student suspected of having a specific learning disability. The psychologist administers both cognitive ability testing and academic achievement testing. What is the primary reason for administering both types of assessments?

choices.A: To compare cognitive functioning and academic skills to interpret learning needs and inform eligibility and intervention planning
choices.B: To ensure the student automatically qualifies for special education services
choices.C: To identify the student's strongest academic subjects only
choices.D: To replace classroom performance and progress monitoring data

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Cognitive testing provides information about how the student processes and reasons, while achievement testing measures current academic skill performance. Using both supports interpretation of learning needs, helps rule out alternative explanations, and informs eligibility and intervention planning. The other options are incorrect because assessment results do not automatically guarantee eligibility, identifying strongest subjects is not the primary purpose of comprehensive assessment, and standardized testing should not replace classroom performance and intervention response data.

question: A parent asks why their child's cognitive test score is average but the achievement test score in math is below average. Which explanation is most accurate?

choices.A: Cognitive tests assess academic content mastery taught in school
choices.B: Achievement tests assess reasoning potential independent of instruction
choices.C: Cognitive tests assess problem-solving ability, while achievement tests assess learned skills
choices.D: Achievement tests assess personality traits, while cognitive tests assess behavior patterns

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Cognitive tests assess reasoning and problem-solving ability, while achievement tests assess skills learned through instruction and experience. The other options are incorrect because they misstate what each test type measures or include unrelated constructs.

question: A fifth-grade student has strong reasoning skills but consistently low performance on reading comprehension tasks that have been taught in class. Which statement best describes the distinction between what an intelligence test and an achievement test measure?

choices.A: Intelligence tests measure learned academic content, while achievement tests measure potential
choices.B: Intelligence tests measure cognitive abilities, while achievement tests measure acquired skills
choices.C: Intelligence tests measure motivation, while achievement tests measure behavior regulation
choices.D: Intelligence tests measure classroom instruction quality, while achievement tests measure effort

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Intelligence tests focus on reasoning and cognitive ability, while achievement tests measure learned knowledge and academic skills. The other options are incorrect because they reverse the constructs or describe factors not directly measured by these tests.

question: Which of the following best describes the difference between intelligence and achievement?

choices.A: Intelligence measures what a student knows; achievement measures learning potential.
choices.B: Intelligence measures reasoning and problem-solving ability; achievement measures learned knowledge and skills.
choices.C: Intelligence is a fixed trait, whereas achievement is fluid and changes daily
choices.D: Intelligence tests are norm-referenced; achievement tests are criterion-referenced.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Intelligence measures cognitive abilities; achievement measures learned content.

question: When assessing a student with a severe physical disability, the school psychologist should:

choices.A: Using the same timeline as typical evaluations
choices.B: Avoiding nonverbal measures to ensure standardization
choices.C: Deferring all assessment decisions to medical professionals
choices.D: Adapt assessment procedures, consider medical factors, involve specialists, and use appropriate accommodations

rationale: Option (D) is correct. Low-incidence exceptionalities = chronic health (diabetes, asthma, epilepsy), severe physical disabilities (cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy), sensory impairments (deaf, blind, deaf-blind). Assessment considerations: adapt procedures, consider medical factors, involve specialists, use appropriate accommodations, understand condition-specific needs. question: When assessing a student with a chronic health condition, the school psychologist should:

choices.A: Deferring all assessment decisions to medical professionals
choices.B: Completing assessment without specialist consultation
choices.C: Adapt assessment procedures, consider medical factors, involve specialists, and use appropriate accommodations
choices.D: Relying solely on norm-referenced cognitive measures

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Low-incidence exceptionalities = chronic health (diabetes, asthma, epilepsy), severe physical disabilities (cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy), sensory impairments (deaf, blind, deaf-blind). Assessment considerations: adapt procedures, consider medical factors, involve specialists, use appropriate accommodations, understand condition-specific needs. question: When assessing a student with a sensory impairment, the school psychologist should:

choices.A: Adapt assessment procedures, consider medical factors, involve specialists, and use appropriate accommodations
choices.B: Relying solely on norm-referenced cognitive measures
choices.C: Using standard assessment procedures without modifications
choices.D: Using the same timeline as typical evaluations

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Low-incidence exceptionalities = chronic health (diabetes, asthma, epilepsy), severe physical disabilities (cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy), sensory impairments (deaf, blind, deaf-blind). question: A school psychologist is helping a teacher choose an assessment to measure students' problem-solving skills in science. Which option best represents a performance-based assessment?

choices.A: Students complete a lab investigation and submit a written analysis
choices.B: Students take a multiple-choice test on science vocabulary terms
choices.C: Students match scientific tools to their definitions on a worksheet
choices.D: Students select the best answer to questions about lab safety rules

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Performance-based assessments require students to demonstrate applied skills through tasks such as investigations and analyses. The other options are incorrect because they primarily assess recognition or recall through selection-based formats.

question: A middle school wants to assess students' persuasive writing skills in a way that reflects real-world performance. Which assessment is the best example of a performance-based assessment?

choices.A: Students write an essay and revise it using a scoring rubric
choices.B: Students answer multiple-choice questions about grammar rules
choices.C: Students complete a true-false quiz on paragraph structure
choices.D: Students select the best topic sentence from four options

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Performance-based assessments require active demonstration of skills, such as producing writing scored with a rubric. The other options are incorrect because they are selection-based formats that measure recognition rather than authentic performance.

question: Which of the following is the best example of a performance-based assessment?

choices.A: A multiple-choice test on math facts
choices.B: A written essay on a historical topic
choices.C: A standardized reading comprehension test
choices.D: A teacher rating scale of student behavior

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Performance-based assessments require students to demonstrate skills through authentic tasks.

question: A problem-solving framework (MTSS/RTI) should be used as the basis for:

choices.A: Applying the same intervention to all struggling students
choices.B: Waiting for failure before providing support
choices.C: All professional activities including assessment, intervention, and decision-making
choices.D: Beginning with comprehensive evaluation for all students

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Problem-solving framework = systematic approach using data to identify problems, analyze causes, implement solutions, and evaluate outcomes. question: A teacher requests immediate placement of a student into an intensive intervention program based only on classroom impressions. What should the school psychologist recommend first within a problem-solving framework?

choices.A: Collect and review data to define the problem before selecting interventions
choices.B: Move the student to the most intensive tier to prevent further failure
choices.C: Wait until the end of the year to compare the student to grade-level peers
choices.D: Begin eligibility testing immediately without intervention planning

rationale: Option (A) is correct. A problem-solving framework begins with defining the problem using data before selecting solutions. The other options are incorrect because they skip analysis, delay action unnecessarily, or jump directly to eligibility testing.

question: A school team notes that multiple students in a second-grade class are performing below benchmark in reading fluency. The team defines the problem, analyzes possible causes, selects an intervention, and monitors progress weekly. This process best reflects which framework?

choices.A: A problem-solving framework emphasizing data-based decisions in MTSS
choices.B: A special education eligibility process limited to students with disabilities
choices.C: A disciplinary framework focusing on consequences for noncompliance
choices.D: A crisis response framework used only after major incidents

rationale: Option (A) is correct. MTSS problem-solving involves identifying problems, analyzing causes, implementing interventions, and evaluating outcomes with data. The other options are incorrect because the process is not limited to eligibility, discipline, or crisis response only.

question: Which of the following is the best way to establish a positive working relationship with a resistant teacher during consultation?

choices.A: Emphasizing the school psychologist's expertise
choices.B: Listening to the teacher's concerns and acknowledging their perspective
choices.C: Telling the teacher what strategies must be implemented
choices.D: Suggesting that the principal mandate the teacher's participation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Active listening and acknowledging concerns builds rapport.

question: During a consultation meeting, a teacher expresses frustration about a student's behavior. The school psychologist responds by summarizing what the teacher said, reflecting the teacher's feelings, and asking clarifying questions. This demonstrates which consultation skill?

choices.A: Active listening
choices.B: Problem-solving
choices.C: Directive guidance
choices.D: Expert consultation

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Active listening involves fully attending to the consultee, summarizing their statements, reflecting feelings, and asking clarifying questions to ensure understanding. This builds rapport and demonstrates that the consultant values the consultee's perspective.

question: A teacher describes a complex situation with a student. The school psychologist responds, 'So if I understand correctly, you're saying that the behavior occurs primarily during transitions and when the student is asked to work independently. Is that accurate?' This response demonstrates:

choices.A: Giving expert advice
choices.B: Paraphrasing to clarify understanding
choices.C: Jumping to solutions
choices.D: Avoiding the problem

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Paraphrasing involves restating what the consultee said in the consultant's own words to confirm understanding and clarify details. This ensures accurate problem identification before moving to analysis or intervention.

question: A teacher is resistant to implementing a recommended intervention, saying 'I've tried everything and nothing works.' The most effective response from the school psychologist is to:

choices.A: Insist that the teacher try the recommended intervention
choices.B: Acknowledge the teacher's concerns, explore barriers, and collaboratively problem-solve
choices.C: Provide more research evidence supporting the intervention
choices.D: Take over and implement the intervention directly

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Resistance is best managed through active listening, acknowledging concerns, exploring barriers (time, resources, training), and maintaining a collaborative problem-solving approach. This builds trust and addresses the root causes of resistance rather than forcing compliance.

question: A school psychologist is facilitating a meeting with teachers, parents, a community mental health provider, and a school administrator to coordinate services for a student. To effectively facilitate communication among these diverse stakeholders, the psychologist should:

choices.A: Ensure all parties understand each other's roles and perspectives
choices.B: Make decisions unilaterally to avoid conflict
choices.C: Focus only on the school's perspective
choices.D: Let each stakeholder speak without facilitation

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Facilitating communication among diverse stakeholders requires clarifying roles, ensuring all perspectives are heard and understood, translating between different professional languages, and building common ground. The consultant serves as a bridge between different systems and perspectives.

question: A school psychologist needs to coordinate services for a student who requires mental health services. What is the most appropriate approach for working with community agencies?

choices.A: Expecting agencies to adapt to school schedules
choices.B: Assuming agencies will communicate with each other
choices.C: Limiting collaboration to crisis situations only
choices.D: Coordinate services by understanding agency roles, facilitating communication between systems, and ensuring seamless service delivery

rationale: Option (D) is correct. question: A school psychologist is presenting results of an evaluation to a student's parents. The psychologist should

choices.A: use technical jargon to demonstrate expertise
choices.B: focus only on the student's weaknesses to justify the need for services
choices.C: explain results in language that is easy for the parents to understand
choices.D: avoid discussing any results that might concern the parents

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Results should be communicated in accessible language that parents can understand.

question: A school psychologist is beginning consultation with a new teacher. The psychologist establishes mutual goals, clarifies roles and expectations, and builds rapport. This represents which stage of consultation?

choices.A: Problem identification
choices.B: Entry/Contracting
choices.C: Problem analysis
choices.D: Intervention implementation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. The entry/contracting stage is the first stage of consultation, where the consultant establishes the relationship, clarifies roles and expectations, sets mutual goals, and builds rapport. This must occur before problem identification or any other stages.

question: During consultation, a school psychologist helps a teacher define a student's problem by collecting baseline data on how often the behavior occurs, when it occurs, and what it looks like. This activity best represents which stage of consultation?

choices.A: Entry/Contracting
choices.B: Problem identification
choices.C: Problem analysis
choices.D: Intervention evaluation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Problem identification involves defining the problem in observable, measurable terms through data collection. This stage establishes what the problem is before analyzing why it occurs. Problem analysis would involve hypothesizing causes after the problem is clearly defined.

question: A school psychologist analyzes collected data to identify patterns, hypothesizes why a behavior is occurring, and determines the function of the behavior. This represents which consultation stage?

choices.A: Problem identification
choices.B: Problem analysis
choices.C: Intervention implementation
choices.D: Evaluation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Problem analysis involves examining data to understand why the problem is occurring, identifying patterns, and developing hypotheses about causes or functions. This occurs after problem identification (what) and before intervention (how to address it).

question: During the intervention stage of consultation, who is responsible for implementing the intervention with the student?

choices.A: The consultant (school psychologist), because they designed the intervention
choices.B: The consultee (teacher), because consultation is an indirect service
choices.C: Both the consultant and consultee together
choices.D: The student, with guidance from the consultant

rationale: Option (B) is correct. In consultation, the consultee (teacher) implements the intervention, not the consultant. Consultation is an indirect service where the consultant helps the consultee help the student. The consultant's role is to support and guide, not to directly implement interventions.

question: A school psychologist collects data after an intervention has been implemented to determine whether the student's behavior improved and whether the intervention should be continued, modified, or discontinued. This represents which stage of consultation?

choices.A: Problem analysis
choices.B: Intervention implementation
choices.C: Evaluation
choices.D: Entry/Contracting

rationale: Option (C) is correct. The evaluation stage involves collecting data to assess intervention effectiveness, comparing outcomes to baseline, and making decisions about continuing, modifying, or discontinuing the intervention. This is the final stage of the consultation cycle.

question: A school psychologist is working with a family from a different cultural background who expresses concerns about the school's approach. What is the most effective strategy?

choices.A: Build trust by understanding family values and adapting communication styles
choices.B: Scheduling meetings at times convenient for school staff
choices.C: Using the same communication approach with all families
choices.D: Focusing primarily on the student's deficits in conversations

question: A school psychologist is consulting with a teacher about a student who has been having difficulty staying on task during independent work time. The teacher has tried several strategies but has not seen improvement. Which of the following should the school psychologist recommend first?

choices.A: Referring the student for a comprehensive evaluation
choices.B: Collecting more detailed data on the specific behaviors and conditions
choices.C: Implementing a token economy system
choices.D: Recommending the student for placement in a more structured classroom

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Collecting detailed data helps identify the function of the behavior before selecting interventions.

question: A school psychologist is reviewing research on a reading intervention program. Which of the following research designs would provide the strongest evidence of the program's effectiveness?

choices.A: A case study of one student who improved after using the program
choices.B: A randomized controlled trial comparing students who used the program to those who did not
choices.C: A survey of teachers who used the program and reported satisfaction
choices.D: A comparison of test scores before and after program implementation without a control group

rationale: Option (B) is correct. RCTs provide the strongest causal evidence.

question: Which of the following is a primary advantage of using multiple regression in research?

choices.A: It determines causation between variables.
choices.B: It allows examination of the relationship between one outcome and multiple predictors.
choices.C: It eliminates the need for control groups.
choices.D: It is easier to compute than correlation.

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Multiple regression examines relationships between multiple predictors and an outcome.

question: A school psychologist is working with a cultural broker to understand how to support a student who recently moved to the district from India. The school psychologist then shares the information from the cultural broker with the teachers to use in the classroom. Which of the following best describes the type of consultation being used?

choices.A: Consultee-centered
choices.B: Multicultural
choices.C: Problem-solving
choices.D: Indirect

rationale: Option (B) is correct. The school psychologist is seeking support related to a new cultural situation.

question: A school psychologist is working with a middle school student who has been experiencing social difficulties. The student reports feeling lonely and having trouble making friends. Which of the following interventions would be most appropriate?

choices.A: Referring the student for individual counseling with an outside therapist
choices.B: Enrolling the student in a social skills group at school
choices.C: Suggesting the parents arrange more playdates for the student
choices.D: Recommending the student be placed in a smaller classroom setting

rationale: Option (B) is correct. A social skills group provides structured practice in a school setting.

question: A school psychologist is conducting a consultation with a teacher about a student's behavior. Which of the following consultation models emphasizes collaboration between the consultant and consultee?

choices.A: Expert consultation
choices.B: Behavioral consultation
choices.C: Mental health consultation
choices.D: Conjoint behavioral consultation

rationale: Option (D) is correct. Conjoint behavioral consultation involves collaboration between home and school.

question: Which of the following cognitive processes is most directly assessed by measures of processing speed?

choices.A: The ability to hold information in mind while working with it
choices.B: The ability to quickly and efficiently perform simple cognitive tasks
choices.C: The ability to reason and solve novel problems
choices.D: The ability to retrieve information from long-term memory

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Processing speed measures quick, efficient completion of simple cognitive tasks.

question: A school psychologist is using behavioral consultation with a teacher to address a student's disruptive classroom behavior. What is the primary characteristic that makes this consultation 'behavioral'?

choices.A: It focuses on the student's observable behaviors and uses data collection
choices.B: It addresses the student's emotional and social needs
choices.C: It improves the teacher's instructional skills
choices.D: It involves both home and school settings

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Behavioral consultation is characterized by its focus on observable, measurable behaviors and systematic data collection to define problems, analyze causes, and evaluate interventions. This distinguishes it from mental health consultation (affect/relationships) and consultee-centered consultation (teacher skills).

question: A school psychologist is consulting with a teacher who reports that a student seems withdrawn, has difficulty forming peer relationships, and appears anxious. The psychologist focuses on understanding the student's emotional experiences and social dynamics. This best represents which type of consultation?

choices.A: Behavioral consultation
choices.B: Mental health consultation
choices.C: Organizational consultation
choices.D: Conjoint behavioral consultation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Mental health consultation is used when addressing students' emotional, social, and relational concerns. It focuses on affect, relationships, and feelings rather than observable behaviors alone. Behavioral consultation would focus on specific observable behaviors and data collection.

question: A school psychologist notices that a teacher consistently struggles with classroom management across multiple students. The psychologist works with the teacher to improve the teacher's skills and knowledge rather than focusing on individual student problems. This best describes which consultation model?

choices.A: Behavioral consultation
choices.B: Consultee-centered consultation
choices.C: Conjoint behavioral consultation
choices.D: Organizational consultation

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Consultee-centered consultation focuses on improving the consultee's (teacher's) skills, knowledge, and capacity rather than solving individual student problems. The focus is on the teacher's approach, not the student's problem. This differs from behavioral consultation which focuses on specific student behaviors.

question: A school psychologist facilitates meetings where both parents and teachers work together to address a student's behavior concerns, with interventions implemented in both home and school settings. This best describes which consultation model?

choices.A: Behavioral consultation
choices.B: Mental health consultation
choices.C: Conjoint behavioral consultation
choices.D: Consultee-centered consultation

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Conjoint behavioral consultation involves collaboration between home AND school, with both parents and teachers participating in the consultation process. Interventions are coordinated across both settings. Standard behavioral consultation typically involves only the school setting.

question: A school psychologist works with the principal and leadership team to implement a school-wide positive behavior support system that affects all students and staff. This consultation is best described as:

choices.A: Behavioral consultation, because it addresses behavior
choices.B: Organizational consultation, because it addresses system-wide change
choices.C: Consultee-centered consultation, because it improves administrator skills
choices.D: Mental health consultation, because it affects school climate

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Organizational consultation addresses system-wide, organizational-level change rather than individual student problems. It focuses on policies, procedures, and structures that affect the entire school. Behavioral consultation focuses on individual student behaviors, not system-wide change.

question: An elementary school recently implemented a new reading program with the goal of reducing referrals. Because this initiative is new for the teachers, the building principal has asked the school psychologist to assist with implementation of the program. Which of the following activities is most appropriate for the school psychologist to participate in when assisting the teachers?

choices.A: Coteaching lessons once weekly to observe the students in the classroom
choices.B: Conducting weekly observations of each classroom to determine if the teachers are correctly following the curriculum and reporting to the principal with information from the observation
choices.C: Taking over for the teacher when implementing the reading program to identify students who might need more individualized support
choices.D: Collaborate with teachers to establish data collection and progress monitoring procedures.

rationale: Option (D) is correct. School psychologists should collaborate with teachers and assist with data collection and progress monitoring.

question: Which of the following is NOT typically a role of the school psychologist in a problem-solving team meeting?

choices.A: Facilitating the meeting and keeping the team focused on the agenda
choices.B: Making the final decision about which interventions to implement
choices.C: Analyzing assessment data and sharing the results with the team
choices.D: Helping the team identify evidence-based interventions

rationale: Option (B) is correct. School psychologists facilitate but do not make unilateral decisions; the team decides together.

question: A school psychologist is asked to help a teacher who is struggling to manage a particularly challenging classroom. Which of the following consultation approaches would be most effective?

choices.A: Taking over the classroom for a day to demonstrate effective strategies
choices.B: Working collaboratively with the teacher to identify problems and develop solutions
choices.C: Providing the teacher with a list of research-based strategies to implement
choices.D: Observing the classroom and reporting findings to the principal

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Collaborative problem-solving is most effective for consultation.

question: Which of the following is the best way for a school psychologist to stay current with evidence-based practices?

choices.A: Relying solely on information from colleagues
choices.B: Engaging in ongoing professional development and reading peer-reviewed research
choices.C: Using the same assessment and intervention approaches learned in graduate school
choices.D: Attending only state-mandated training sessions

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Ongoing PD and reading research keeps practice current.

question: A teacher asks a school psychologist, 'What should I do about this student's behavior?' The psychologist responds by asking questions to help the teacher think through options rather than immediately providing solutions. This approach:

choices.A: Avoids the expert trap and promotes consultee ownership
choices.B: Shows the psychologist doesn't know the answer
choices.C: Wastes time when the psychologist could just provide the solution
choices.D: Is inappropriate because teachers expect expert advice

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Effective consultation avoids the 'expert trap' where the consultant provides all answers. Instead, consultants use questioning to help consultees develop their own solutions, which promotes ownership, skill development, and sustainable change.

question: A third-grade student scores slightly below benchmark on a universal reading screener. Classroom instruction has been consistent, and the student needs additional practice with decoding in a small-group setting. Which intervention tier is most appropriate?

choices.A: Tier 1 core instruction delivered to all students
choices.B: Tier 2 targeted intervention in a small-group setting
choices.C: Tier 3 intensive intervention delivered individually each day
choices.D: Special education services provided without documented intervention

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Students slightly below benchmark typically receive Tier 2 targeted small-group intervention. The other options are incorrect because Tier 1 is universal only, Tier 3 is for more intensive needs, and special education requires a separate process.

question: A sixth-grade student has not responded to multiple rounds of targeted small-group reading intervention and remains far below grade-level expectations. The team is considering next steps within MTSS. Which tier best matches the level of support needed?

choices.A: Tier 1 universal supports with routine differentiation only
choices.B: Tier 2 targeted supports with brief group instruction weekly
choices.C: Tier 3 intensive supports with individualized intervention and monitoring
choices.D: Tier 1 supports with reduced academic demands for the entire class

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Tier 3 is intensive and individualized for students significantly below benchmark who do not respond to Tier 2. The other options are incorrect because they provide insufficient intensity or inappropriately change supports for the whole class.

question: A school psychologist is evaluating a student for possible autism spectrum disorder. Which of the following assessment approaches would be most appropriate?

choices.A: Administering only standardized cognitive and achievement tests
choices.B: Using multiple sources of information including observation, interviews, and rating scales
choices.C: Relying primarily on parent report of early developmental history
choices.D: Focusing exclusively on academic performance data

rationale: Option (B) is correct. ASD evaluation requires multiple sources and methods.

question: According to NASP's Model for Comprehensive and Integrated School Psychological Services, which of the following is considered a foundational domain?

choices.A: Data-based decision making
choices.B: Consultation and collaboration
choices.C: Legal, ethical, and professional practice
choices.D: Interventions and instructional support

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Legal, ethical, and professional practice is considered a foundational domain.

question: Which of the following is a key component of effective parent-school communication?

choices.A: Limiting contact to formal meetings only
choices.B: Using jargon to demonstrate professional expertise
choices.C: Establishing regular, two-way communication channels
choices.D: Communicating primarily through written reports

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Regular two-way communication supports effective partnerships.

question: A fourth-grade student makes frequent regrouping errors in multi-digit subtraction, even when basic facts are accurate. Which action is most appropriate before choosing an intervention?

choices.A: Review the student's error patterns to identify the precise skill breakdown
choices.B: Assign additional homework on all math topics to increase practice
choices.C: Provide a general study skills program focused on organization habits
choices.D: Move the student to a higher-level math group to increase expectations

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Identifying the specific error pattern helps determine the targeted instructional need. The other options are incorrect because they are generic or mismatched to the underlying skill deficit.

question: A second-grade student consistently reads "ship" as "sip" and "thin" as "tin" during oral reading. Before selecting an intervention, what should the school psychologist recommend the teacher do?

choices.A: Analyze the error pattern to determine the specific phonics skill deficit
choices.B: Begin a general reading intervention focused on increasing reading time
choices.C: Move the student to harder texts to increase challenge and effort
choices.D: Reduce reading instruction until the student shows more motivation

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Error pattern analysis identifies the specific skill deficit and guides appropriate intervention selection. The other options are incorrect because they are not targeted to the error pattern and may reduce effectiveness.

question: A school psychologist is working with a student who has experienced a traumatic event. The student has been having nightmares and flashbacks. Which of the following interventions would be most appropriate?

choices.A: Requiring the student to describe the traumatic event in detail
choices.B: Referring the student to a trauma-focused mental health specialist
choices.C: Telling the student to try not to think about what happened
choices.D: Focusing only on academic performance

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Students with significant trauma symptoms should be referred to specialists.

question: Which of the following is the best example of a functional behavior assessment (FBA)?

choices.A: Completing a cognitive and achievement assessment for the purpose of identifying a specific learning disability
choices.B: Analyzing data to identify academic difficulties that can be addressed with interventions
choices.C: Completing an observation and interview for the purpose of identifying the function of a student's problem behavior
choices.D: Completing a depression screening for the purpose of identifying mental health concerns

rationale: Option (C) is correct. FBAs are used to understand the function of a student's behavior and what conditions maintain the behavior.

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate role for a school psychologist during a crisis response?

choices.A: Providing long-term individual therapy to affected students
choices.B: Offering immediate psychological first aid and support
choices.C: Conducting comprehensive mental health evaluations
choices.D: Assigning students to support groups based on diagnosis

rationale: Option (B) is correct. During crisis response, immediate psychological first aid is the primary role.

question: A fifth-grade student reads a grade-level passage with 96% word-reading accuracy and adequate comprehension with teacher support. Based on the accuracy rate, the passage is at what reading level for instruction?

choices.A: Independent level because the student can read without support
choices.B: Instructional level because accuracy is within the teaching range
choices.C: Frustration level because accuracy is below the expected threshold
choices.D: Listening level because accuracy is unrelated to text difficulty

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Instructional level is typically 93% to 97% accuracy, which is appropriate for teaching with support. The other options are incorrect because independent level is usually 95% to 100% without support, frustration level is below 93%, and listening level does not define accuracy thresholds.

question: A school psychologist conducts a reading assessment and finds that a student reads a second-grade passage with 88% accuracy. Based on this accuracy level, which of the following best describes the appropriate instructional use of this text?

choices.A: This is at the student's independent level and appropriate for homework
choices.B: This is at the student's instructional level and optimal for teaching
choices.C: This is at the student's frustration level and too difficult for instruction
choices.D: This accuracy level indicates the student needs intensive intervention

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Accuracy below typical instructional thresholds indicates frustration level, meaning the text is too difficult and will likely lead to breakdowns in reading and comprehension. The other options are incorrect because independent level requires much higher accuracy, instructional level is higher than this accuracy level, and while intervention may be needed, the question is asking specifically about appropriate instructional use of the text.

question: A teacher wants to select appropriate reading materials for a student to practice independently at home. Assessment data shows the student reads grade-level texts with 99% accuracy. Which of the following recommendations should the school psychologist make?

choices.A: The student should practice with more challenging texts to build skills
choices.B: The student should use texts at this level for independent practice
choices.C: The student needs teacher support when reading texts at this level
choices.D: The student should only read texts with 100% accuracy independently

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Very high accuracy indicates the student can read the text successfully without adult support, which makes the text appropriate for independent practice. The other options are incorrect because jumping to more challenging texts is not necessary for independent practice, teacher support is not indicated at this accuracy level, and requiring exactly 100% accuracy is unnecessarily restrictive for independent reading.

question: A third-grade student reads a passage with 90% word-reading accuracy and shows increasing frustration during the task. Based on the accuracy rate, this text is best classified as which level?

choices.A: Independent level because accuracy is above 85%
choices.B: Instructional level because accuracy is near 95%
choices.C: Frustration level because accuracy is below 93%
choices.D: Mastery level because the student attempted all words

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Frustration level texts are typically below 93% accuracy and are too difficult for effective instruction. The other options are incorrect because independent and instructional levels require higher accuracy, and mastery level is not the standard classification used here.

question: A school psychologist is working with a student who has autism spectrum disorder. The student becomes very upset when routines are changed. Which of the following strategies would be most helpful?

choices.A: Eliminating all changes to the student's routine
choices.B: Providing advance notice and visual supports before changes occur
choices.C: Ignoring the student's distress until it passes
choices.D: Requiring the student to adapt to changes without support

rationale: Option (B) is correct. Advance notice and visual supports help students with ASD manage transitions.

question: A student's academic progress is influenced by socioeconomic factors. Which factor is most likely to impact achievement?

choices.A: Cultural background is irrelevant to learning
choices.B: Student intelligence is the primary factor in achievement
choices.C: Access to resources and stability
choices.D: Motivation alone determines academic success

rationale: Option (C) is correct. Academic progress is influenced by multiple factors: classroom climate, family involvement, socioeconomic resources, and environmental stability. question: A student with a sensory impairment needs assistive technology for writing. This is an example of:

choices.A: An accommodation (changes how the student accesses the curriculum)
choices.B: A related service provided by a specialist
choices.C: A supplementary aid for general education access
choices.D: A transition service for post-school outcomes

rationale: Option (A) is correct. Accommodation = changes HOW (extended time, read aloud, assistive technology). Modification = changes WHAT (reduced content, altered standards).
